keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.'
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest but an AR-15 assault rifle was found in his vehicle outside the airport.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in the commission of a felony, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.

Cagle is also charged with federal offenses including attempted violence at an international airport, interstate communications containing threats to injure, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.
Cagle previously was convicted of marijuana possession over 20 years ago and lives in Cartersville, Georgia.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens emphasized that Cagle's mental health and possession of a semi-automatic weapon created a deadly combination.
Cagle’s family had alerted Cartersville police via social media that he was armed and heading to the airport, prompting a police alert and coordination with Atlanta PD.
Authorities discovered Cagle had already arrived at the airport at the south terminal, where he was observed near the heavily crowded TSA check-in area.
Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world, handling over 108 million passengers annually and serving as the headquarters for Delta Air Lines.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised law enforcement for preventing a potential tragedy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted law enforcement that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.' Though unarmed at the time of arrest, police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle faces multiple state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assaults, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm. Authorities discovered he had already arrived at the airport, where surveillance showed him near the crowded TSA check-in area. The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and officials like Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem emphasized the severity of the threat due to the combination of mental health concerns and firearm possession. The incident occurred at the world’s busiest airport, highlighting risks in high-traffic environments and the importance of public vigilance and inter-agency coordination.
title: Man Arrested Inside Atlanta Airport After Making Threats to ‘Shoot It Up’
